;周三，英国首相里希·苏纳克 (Rishi Sunak) 向 LGBTQ 退伍军人道歉，这些退伍军人在 2000 年同性恋禁令取消之前，在军队服役期间遭受了性虐待、暴力、欺凌和骚扰。

;

;欧洲人权法院驳回了一项关于需要保护军队士气和战斗力的论点，称该政策侵犯了人权，之后英国才取消了禁令。 .

;

;在此之前，许多同性恋者试图隐藏自己的性取向，否则就有被军队开除的风险。

;

;英国 LGBTQ 退伍军人接受转化治疗和政治迫害：报告

;

;去年启动了一项独立审查，审查 1967 年至 2000 年间服役的 LGBTQ 退伍军人的证词，以认识到这些政策的影响。该评论于周三发表。

;

;苏纳克周三向下议院全体议员表示，该禁令是“英国政府的一次令人震惊的失败”。

;

;“正如今天的报告所表明的那样，在那段时期，许多人在勇敢地为这个国家服务的同时忍受了最可怕的性虐待和暴力、恐同欺凌和骚扰，”他说。

;

;“我代表英国政府道歉。”

;< p>;报告称，公开征集证据已收到超过 1,120 份答复，其中包括约 300 份来自因 LGBTQ 同性性行为和同性恋取向而被解雇或退伍的退伍军人。

;

;英国国防部长本·华莱士表示，这次审查揭示了“我们武装部队历史上可耻且不可接受的历史篇章”。

;

;华莱士在向议会发表的一份声明中表示，审查提出了 49 项建议他表示，政府原则上接受了这些建议中的绝大多数，并将在议会暑假后做出全面回应。

;

;同性恋于 1967 年在英格兰和威尔士以及 20 世纪 80 年代初在整个英国合法化。

; Wed, 19 Jul 2023 21:50:02 +0800 Fast-fashion feud: Temu sues Chinese rival Shein in US for bullying suppliershttps://www.scmp.com/tech/tech-trends/article/3228232/fast-fashion-feud-temu-sues-chinese-rival-shein-us-bullying-suppliers?utm_source=rss_feed

;;2023.07.19 21:00;
;;

;中国增长最快的两家在线零售平台在美国卷入了一场不寻常的法律战，他们的赤裸裸的竞争蔓延到了中国最大、利润最丰厚的市场之一的法庭。

;

;根据一份报告，上海拼多多控股有限公司旗下的 Temu 起诉了其竞争对手 Shein，该公司成立于南京，总部位于新加坡，指控其违反反垄断法和消费者权益法。 7 月 14 日向马萨诸塞州地方法院提起诉讼。 Temu 寻求未具体说明的金钱赔偿。

;

;“Shein 参与了一场威胁、恐吓、虚假侵权指控的活动，并试图施加毫无根据的惩罚性罚款，”Temu 写道。

;

;“长期以来，我们一直保持着极大的克制，没有采取法律行动。然而，Shein 不断升级的攻击让我们别无选择，只能采取法律措施来捍卫我们的权利。”Temu 在另一份声明中表示。

;

;根据周三的一份电子邮件声明，Shein 表示该诉讼“没有法律依据”，并誓言“大力辩护”。

;

;在国内经济增长乏力的情况下，全球市场对中国企业变得越来越重要。随着消费者收紧钱包，这个世界第二大经济体的零售额 6 月份同比仅增长 3.1%，低于 5 月份的 12.7%。

;

;虽然中国电子商务市场的竞争变得越来越残酷，但 Shein 和 Temu 等公司凭借主要由中国制造商生产的低成本产品，成功在海外市场找到了新的机会。

;

;美国是 Shein 继其之后的最大市场。巴西——自 Covid-19 大流行开始以来，该公司一直处于连胜状态。 2020年1月，它占该国快时尚销售额的12%。根据彭博社第二次衡量，到 2022 年 11 月，其份额升至 50%，超过了 H&M 集团、Zara、ASOS 和 Forever 21 等知名竞争对手。

;

;但 Shein 的崛起受到了 Temu 的威胁。Temu 于 9 月在美国推出，销售更广泛的产品，并将自己定位为比 Shein 更便宜的选择。

;

;Temu 在 2019 年第一季度的下载量猛增了 57%。 2023 年，根据移动情报公司 Sensor Tower 的数据，在苹果 App Store 和 Google Play 上均名列前茅。

;

;Temu 在上周向马萨诸塞州提起的诉讼中声称，在进入美国后，Shein 开始强迫服装制造商签署忠诚誓言，否则将面临“巨额罚款和处罚”。

;

;“Shein 知道制造商需要[其]销量以及进入美国市场的机会，因此它能够强迫制造商作出安排，迫使制造商不与其开展业务Temu”，PDD 子公司表示。

;

;Temu 声称，截至 5 月份，Shein 已向约 8,338 家制造商施压，要求其签署独家经销协议。该公司表示，结果，商家不得不从 Temu 上撤下 10,000 多个商品，并补充说，这一结果损害了美国商家和消费者的利益。

;

;随着 Shein 和 Temu 之间的商业竞争升温，他们的法律纠纷也愈演愈烈。

;

;在今年早些时候向芝加哥地方法院提起的诉讼中，Shein 指控 Temu 侵犯了其商标和版权，并使用了不公平的商业行为，例如在社交媒体上冒充其品牌。并与有影响力的人合作贬低其业务。 Temu 驳回该案的请求尚未确定。

;

;但 Temu 和 Shein 面临的挑战超出了他们自己的竞争范围。

;

;随着华盛顿对中国应用程序的审查力度加大，立法者上个月向国会提出了两党法案，提议取消允许 Temu 和 Shein 等公司向美国免税运送低价值中国商品的美国出口豁免。

;

;4 月，一份联邦政府报告指责 Shein 和 Temu 构成数据风险，并提出了对进口非法物品的担忧，例如违反知识产权或美国《2021 年维吾尔族强迫劳动预防法》的物品。

;

;另外，Shein 正在为一群设计师提起的诉讼进行辩护，这些设计师上周在洛杉矶联邦法院起诉该公司，指控其设计和产品侵犯版权。

;

;Temu 周三表示，对 Shein 的诉讼旨在恢复市场秩序。

;

;“我们的法律措施旨在让对方回到基于规则的公平竞争，这将有利于生态系统中的所有参与者，包括消费者、供应商和服务提供商。”Temu 说。

; Wed, 19 Jul 2023 21:20:02 +0800 China’s economic slowdown to have ‘global repercussions’ beyond trade, hinder current account recovery, IMF sayshttps://www.scmp.com/economy/china-economy/article/3228250/chinas-economic-slowdown-have-global-repercussions-beyond-trade-hinder-current-account-recovery-imf?utm_source=rss_feed
;;2023.07.19 21:00;
;;

;国际货币基金组织 (IMF) 周三表示，中国在新冠疫情后缓慢的复苏可能会阻碍今年全球经常账户余额预期的收窄，而世界第二大经济体的经济放缓也将与强势美元一起给脆弱的新兴市场带来压力。

;

;在该基金组织的年度《对外部门报告》中指出的下行风险出现之际，中国公布的经济增长速度低于预期。 - 预计第二季度同比增长 6.3%，人们的担忧立即超出了其增长势头和全年目标。

;

;这家总部位于华盛顿的机构警告称，“中国复苏弱于预期将直接影响其贸易伙伴，其中最大的贸易伙伴位于亚太地区。”

;

;该基金组织今年早些时候表示，中国今年将对全球增长的贡献率超过 30%。

;

;不过，国际货币基金组织， IMF 没有调整 4 月份《世界经济展望》中对中国 5.2% 的年增长率预期，也没有调整 2.8% 的全球增长率预测。

;

;国际货币基金组织最新报告补充道，“经济放缓还将影响到中国在全球需求中占很大份额的大宗商品，从而对中国主要贸易伙伴以外的全球产生影响。”

;

;中国是沙特阿拉伯和俄罗斯原油、澳大利亚铁矿石、巴西大豆和美国原油的全球主要买家。

;

;国际货币基金组织估计，去年全球经常账户余额（一国与世界其他国家的国际交易记录）扩大的情况可能会在2023年得到扭转。

;

;中国的商品贸易顺差很大，因为出口大于进口，但据报道，中国也有很大的服务贸易逆差。

;

;今年上半年，中国的商品贸易顺差为4090亿美元，比去年同期增长9.7%海关数据显示，中国第一季度经常账户顺差为 815 亿美元。

;

;然而，国际货币基金组织表示，由于出境旅游和支出预计将飙升，中国的贸易顺差可能在 2023 年剩余时间内缩小。

;

;这可能有助于在今年晚些时候缩小全球经常账户余额，同时美国公共储蓄增加和大宗商品价格下跌。 ”

;

;国际货币基金组织在其最新报告中还预测，北京可能会继续实现海外证券投资多元化，以减少对强势美元的依赖。

;

;“在中国逐步金融开放的背景下，增加证券投资预计将进一步实现海外资产和负债的多元化。”

;

;在收益率下降和华盛顿金融制裁威胁日益加大的情况下，中国已连续七年减持美国国债。直到 2 月份，中国的外汇储备连续几个月略有回升。

;

;继 3 月份小幅回升之后，减持继续进行，根据美国财政部的数据，5 月份的持有量减少了 222 亿美元，至 8,467 亿美元，为 2010 年 5 月以来的最低水平。

;

;国际货币基金组织表示，总体而言，中国去年的对外头寸“与中期基本面和理想政策所暗示的水平大致相符”。

;

;不过，北京方面应该加快市场-报告建议，应基于结构性改革，将财政政策支持转向加强社会保护，以提振私人消费，并进一步提高汇率灵活性，以帮助吸收外部冲击。

;

;“复苏每况愈下”：中国经济数据的六大要点

;

;国际货币基金组织补充说，去年中国经常项目顺差占国内生产总值的2.2%。

;

;不过，顺差预计将收窄，并恢复与新冠疫情相关的下降趋势报告称，因素正在缓解，私人消费恢复再平衡。

;

;国际货币基金组织在 2022 年评估中还表示，北京方面没有对外汇市场进行大规模干预。

; Wed, 19 Jul 2023 21:20:02 +0800 Why US may have ‘sense of urgency’ to improve military ties with Chinahttps://www.scmp.com/news/china/military/article/3228260/why-us-may-have-sense-urgency-improve-military-ties-china?utm_source=rss_feed

;当美国资深外交官、百岁老人亨利·基辛格周二突然访问北京时，中国国防部长是他会见的第一位官员。

;

;与李尚福将军的会面正值两国军事关系因地缘政治紧张局势和制裁而紧张之际，而李本人也在华盛顿的制裁名单上。

;

;此前，谢锋上周在五角大楼举行了罕见的会谈，中国驻美国大使和美国负责印太安全事务的助理国防部长伊利·拉特纳。

;

;中国社会科学院美中关系研究员卢翔表示，美国可能比中国更有恢复两军沟通的紧迫感。

;

;卢翔表示，这种紧迫感来自于解放军在台湾附近的活动，自南希·佩洛西访问台湾以来，这些活动加剧了。去年 8 月，她在担任美国众议院议长期间，台湾成为了一个自治岛屿。

;

;北京 — — 宣称台湾是自己的，并认为佩洛西此行侵犯了其主权 — — 通过切断军事战区司令部领导人之间的对话以及与美国国防部的工作会议进行报复。

;

;现在，解放军几乎每天都派战机和舰艇靠近台湾岛，迫使台湾军方紧急升空回应。

;

;大多数国家不承认台湾是台湾的领土。卢说，“美国希望利用与中国的军事接触，试图让解放军减少在台湾附近的军事活动。” “这应该可以解释其紧迫感。”

;

;华盛顿表示，北京拒绝了国防部长劳埃德·奥斯汀和李克强之间的会谈。这位中国国防部长在2018年帮助中国从俄罗斯主要武器出口国购买Su-35战斗机和设备后受到美国政府制裁。美国早些时候因俄罗斯国防出口公司违反美国限制与伊朗、朝鲜和叙利亚武器贸易的法律而对其实施制裁。

;

;中国表示，美国不解除制裁，拒绝为对话创造必要条件。这些制裁并不妨碍李克强与奥斯汀对话。

;

;众议院小组谴责中国气球事件后美国的外交努力

;

;华盛顿已派出多名官员前往北京推动缓和，其中包括国务卿安东尼·布林肯、财政部长珍妮特·耶伦和总统气候特使约翰·克里。北京还正在与华盛顿商谈，安排商务部长吉娜·雷蒙多访问。

;

;基辛格作为时任总统理查德·尼克松的国家安全顾问，于 1971 年对中国进行了秘密访问，尽管冷战时期存在意识形态分歧，但为两国关系正常化铺平了道路。此后他多次访问中国，包括在担任美国国务卿期间。

;

;美国国务院表示，布林肯6月份访华时，已从北京方面获悉基辛格计划访华。据称，基辛格是自愿来华的，并不代表华盛顿。

;

;清华大学国际安全与战略研究中心高级研究员周波表示，基辛格与李克强的会面不足以改善军事关系。

;

;解放军退役大校周表示，“基辛格或许可以传达一些信息。”

;

;“但我认为这次会面对改善关系没有太大用处，因为中国已经非常明确地表明了自己的立场。无论是通过国防部还是外交部，中国对于解除对李部长的制裁的立场都非常坚定。”

;

;周不相信华盛顿会解除制裁。 “但美国没有其他出路，我不确定它打算做什么。”

;

;基辛格最后一次见到中国高级国防官员是在2019年，当时他与时任中央军委副主席的徐其亮将军讨论了美中军事关系。

; Wed, 19 Jul 2023 21:20:02 +0800 Mystery over missing Chinese Foreign Minister Qin Gang takes toll on country’s international imagehttps://www.scmp.com/news/china/diplomacy/article/3228262/mystery-over-missing-chinese-foreign-minister-qin-gang-takes-toll-countrys-international-image?utm_source=rss_feed
;;2023.07.19 20:46;
;;

;现在是中国外交的旺季，过去和现在的世界领导人在过去一个月访问北京，但中国外交部长却明显缺席。

;

;被认为是国家形象的秦刚自 6 月 25 日以来就消失在公众视野中，错过了印度尼西亚地区外长聚会和美国高级人物的多次访问等重要活动。

;

;因此尽管外界猜测越来越多，但北京方面一直对他的行踪守口如瓶，将他的缺席归咎于未具体说明的“健康原因”。

;

;外交观察人士表示，七个月前由国家主席习近平亲自挑选的秦先生的长期缺席似乎让中国陷入了巨大的尴尬。

;

;他们还警告说，北京方面无法揭露他失踪的秘密，这也引发了人们对中国不透明决策的许多质疑。

;

; p>;

;华盛顿史汀生中心中国项目主任孙云表示，北京的简洁解释无法令人信服。

;

;“看来北京的信息变得更加集中——秦有健康问题，”她说。 “很少有人相信这一点，但对中国来说，有一个可以坚持、可以坚持的解释很重要。”

;

;欧盟外交事务负责人何塞普·博雷尔(Josep Borrell)着眼于10月份的中国之行

;

;据外交部称，秦最后一次公开露面是在6月25日会见俄罗斯、越南和斯里兰卡的高级外交官时。

;

;他原定于上周会见欧盟外交政策负责人何塞普·博雷尔(Josep Borrell)，但北京突然取消了这次行程，称亚洲协会政策研究所中国分析中心高级研究员菲利普·勒科尔 (Philippe Le Corre) 表示，在没有进一步解释的情况下取消对欧洲人来说是一个重大“意外，甚至是尴尬”。

;

;7月7日，外交部首次被问及取消的背后是否有健康原因，但其发言人汪文斌表示，他“没有听说过此事”。

;

;但仅仅四天后，王说秦将错过东南亚国家联盟因“健康原因”在印度尼西亚首都雅加达举行会议，但没有详细说明。

;

;过去几周，国内外社交媒体上关于秦的遭遇的谣言铺天盖地。

;

;周一，当被问及秦神秘失踪的消息时，另一位外交部发言人毛宁表示，她“没有任何信息”。

;

;但有趣的是，这些有关秦下落的问题和评论在外交部的信息中却缺失了。网站。

;

;同一天，美国国务院表示，当中国外交政策负责人王毅在东盟会议上与美国国务卿安东尼·布林肯会面时，中国外交部长王毅代替外交部长，被告知秦正“处理健康问题”。

;

;“对于任何其他国家来说，这将被视为巨大的外交尴尬。但在中国，政治始终占据主导地位。勒科尔表示，外交是二流活动，外交部长通常没有那么大的权力。

;

;

;

;“当涉及到中国的声誉和外交时，此案被认为是党内事务，我认为中国当局并不真正关心这件事如何向外界传播或看起来。”

;

;

;但是，她继续说：“如果有什么丑闻，北京显然不想证实这一点。”没有丑闻，北京仍然必须表现出确定他的健康问题足够严重，并且北京有后备计划，这也需要时间。”

;

;

;他表示，秦的缺席和北京的处理方式表明中国正在变得更加专制，“无疑会给中国的一人政治增加更多不确定性，使外国政府和投资者更难确定和预测”。

; Wed, 19 Jul 2023 20:20:02 +0800 Victoria state’s shock axing of 2026 Commonwealth Games cheered in Australia as living costs surgehttps://www.scmp.com/week-asia/politics/article/3228258/victoria-states-shock-axing-commonwealth-games-cheered-australia-living-costs-surge?utm_source=rss_feed

;;

;The shock cancellation of the 2026 Commonwealth Games in Australia's Victoria state, owing to a budget blowout that more than doubled original cost estimates, has received domestic approval amid surging living costs but left athletes from participating nations in limbo.

;

;Victoria State Premier Dan Andrews' decision on Tuesday not to host the 2026 event stunned the sporting world and infuriated major organising bodies, including the Commonwealth Games Federation (CGF), as higher-than-expected costs in logistics and possibly construction made it impossible for officials to deliver the event on budget.

;

;This Week in Asia reached out to participating nations in the region, including Bangladesh, India, Malaysia, Pakistan and Singapore, but did not receive any responses at the time of publication about the impact that the move would have on their athletes.

;

;Since Victoria state was appointed host last April, the budget for the games has ballooned to more than A$6 billion (US$4 billion) from an original A$2.6 billion – and the costs would be double the estimated economic benefits to the state.

;

;The state will continue to fund housing and world-class sporting facilities promised as part of the games, mainly A$2 billion on facilities and A$1 billion on affordable housing, even as it pulls out of the event.

;

;Premier Andrews said the state government would soon provide an “accounting” for the blowout, as questions emerge whether it was due to poor budgeting on a complex and untested multi-city model where various regional towns would be used to host events, or if the costs were hit by inflation.

;

;At the time of the bid in early 2022, the consumer price index for Australia stood at about 3.5-5 per cent. Today, it is 7 per cent.

;

;At a lengthy press conference on Tuesday, Premier Andrews said the rising cost of living that was hurting many Australians made it difficult to justify hosting the games.

;

;“You've made your best estimates … and you go and do the work in a pretty volatile economic climate and you get actuals … Do you push on and deliver this at any cost? Take your money out of hospitals and schools and roads, out of all manner of different things to pay for it, or do you make the decision we've announced today?” he said.

;

;“The cost of this is at least A$6 billion and potentially substantially more than that, and I simply will not spend that on a 12-day sporting event.”

;

;Andrews also alluded to the fact there could be several kinds of blowouts.

;

;Stadium and housing upgrades already accounted for some of the rising construction costs, and there were unforeseen expenses “in terms of services, security, transport … bills that will be paid to contractors to those who provide services to those who do all the logistics”.

;

;Andrews added the state would also save on the costs of taking down temporary buildings erected for the games that could stretch months after the event.

;

;Australia axes 2026 Commonwealth Games, blames ballooning cost of hosting event

;

;A statement by the CGF also offered clues on the blowouts, referring to “price escalation” surrounding “village and venue builds, and transport infrastructure”.

;

;Andrews' critics have accused him of tarnishing Australia's international reputation, while the federation and Commonwealth Games Australia accused the Victoria government of “gross exaggeration” of the cost overruns and blindsiding them on the decision.

;

;The chief executive of Commonwealth Games Australia also said the government had ignored its recommendations to reduce costs by holding the competitions only in Melbourne, but Andrews on Tuesday said his government had exhausted all alternative plans.

;

;Tom Heenan, a lecturer in sport and Australian studies at Monash University, said the cancellation showed that hosting mega-events like the Commonwealth Games was not worth it. “This venture was flawed from the start. Situating the games in regional centres highlighted their declining global importance,” he said.

;

;Other states have declined to replace Victoria in hosting the event, all citing prohibitive costs.

;

;Perth Mayor Basil Zempilas said in a local interview it would only host at the right price, not A$7 billion (US$4.7 billion). New South Wales Premier Chris Minns ruled out the opportunity instantly, saying the state's fiscal position was tight.

;

;Many netizens and Australians supported Premier Andrews' decision to save money on a sporting event few cared about, with the hashtag #IStandWithDan trending on Twitter over the past day.

;

;Over the years, there have been few takers to host the games, and Victoria was the only formal applicant for the 2026 event.

;

;Others accused Andrews and his government of mismanaging the state's finances.

;

;On Wednesday, Australian Prime Minister Anthony Albanese was confronted with more complaints about cost of living during a local interview and was asked if the nation was in a “crisis”.

;

;Australia, a major sporting nation, took out the biggest haul of medals at the 2022 Commonwealth Games in Birmingham, England.

;

;Additional reporting by AFP

;Samsung Electronics and Apple continued to dominate the global smartphone market in the three months ended June 30, while leading the premium handset segment, as the industry saw worldwide sales decline for the eighth consecutive quarter, according to the latest report from Counterpoint Research.

;

;The world's No 3 smartphone vendor Xiaomi, by contrast, faced headwinds in its two biggest markets, China and India, during the same period, Counterpoint said in its report published on Tuesday.

;

;Global smartphone sales decreased 8 per cent year on year and 5 per cent quarter on quarter in the three months ended June, it said.

;

;Samsung topped overall industry sales in the second quarter with a 22 per cent share, driven by the strong global performance of its Galaxy A-series smartphones. The South Korean giant, however, saw total sales last quarter fall 12 per cent from the same period last year.

;

;Apple – the world's most valuable company, with a market capitalisation of US$3 trillion as of Tuesday – recorded its highest-ever second-quarter market share at 17 per cent, according to Counterpoint.

;

;Although Apple's overall worldwide sales declined 2 per cent last quarter compared to the same period last year, the Cupertino, California-based company's strength in the premium segment enabled its sales in India, the world's second-biggest smartphone market behind China, to grow a record 50 per cent in the three months ended June.

;

;The strong sales performance of Samsung and Apple underscored how the global smartphone market's premium segment, where handsets cost more than US$600 each, has become immune to broader constraints across the industry.

;

;More than one out of five smartphones sold globally during the second quarter belonged to the premium segment, according to Counterpoint. It said the segment was the only one that grew during that period, reaching its highest-ever second-quarter contribution to the overall market.

;

;Apple expands sales reach in China with WeChat online store

;

;The global smartphone market, according to Counterpoint, “now seems to be well past its rapid growth phase”. It indicated that more consumers are holding on to their devices longer amid a slowing economy, which has squeezed the demand for entry-level and mid-market handsets.

;

;Beijing-based Xiaomi, meanwhile, kept its No 3 ranking in global smartphone sales in the second quarter with a 12 per cent market share, but saw a 12 per cent overall decrease in sales worldwide during the period, according to Counterpoint.

;

;“The brand is looking to offset such declines with expansion in other markets and by refreshing its portfolio,” the research firm said.

;

;Oppo, whose sales last quarter include those of its OnePlus brand, held on to its 10 per cent share in the global market, despite registering losses in western Europe, according to Counterpoint.

;

;Smartphone giant Xiaomi pushes bricks-and-mortar retail expansion in India

;

;Vivo, which had an 8 per cent share in global smartphone sales last quarter, saw a major growth deterioration in China amid strong competition from Samsung. Counterpoint said it also faced stiff competition from Oppo in India and markets in Southeast Asia.

;

;China's 618 shopping festival on June 18, the second most important e-commerce event in the country after Singles' Day in November, helped arrest the decline in domestic smartphone sales, Counterpoint said.

;

;But weak consumer spending saw China's top retail platform operators, Alibaba Group Holding's Taobao & Tmall Business Group and JD.com, not report gross merchandise value figures, which companies have used in the past to trumpet their success at moving product during major shopping festivals. Alibaba owns the South China Morning Post.

;

;Still, Counterpoint said it expected the global market “to recover slowly in the coming quarters”. It said smartphone vendors are likely to launch new models in the second half of 2023, which could “attract consumers to replace and upgrade their devices”.

;A doctor has been charged with fraud for allegedly deceiving Hong Kong's Hospital Authority into paying him more than HK$110,000 (US$14,077) for extra services he was not performing.

;

;Wong Man-ho, 33, a resident doctor at Yan Chai Hospital in Tsuen Wan, allegedly made false declarations about the hours he worked at other hospitals more than 60 times between 2017 and 2019, the Independent Commission Against Corruption (ICAC) said on Wednesday.

;

;Wong joined the authority in 2013 and has been a resident doctor at Yan Chai Hospital since January 2017.

;

;The ICAC said Wong generally worked from 9am to 5pm on weekdays and 9am to 1pm on Saturdays. Sometimes he would perform on-call duty rotation.

;

;The anti-graft agency alleged that Wong deceived the Hospital Authority into paying him HK$110,000 through false declarations on his attendance records related to services he performed at Tuen Mun Hospital's Accident and Emergencies Department.

;

;Hong Kong law professor faces fraud charge over HK$700,000 rent claim

;

;The Hospital Authority provides medical staff with a special honorarium on an hourly basis for extra tasks performed outside their “normal duties”, to cope with excessive service demands, the ICAC said.

;

;An investigation, triggered by a corruption complaint referred from the Hospital Authority, found that Wong's normal hours at Yan Chai Hospital overlapped with his reported hours at Tuen Mun Hospital over 60 times between 2017 and 2019, amounting to 170 hours.

;

;Wong was charged with one count of fraud by the anti-graft agency and released on bail. He is expected to appear in the West Kowloon Court on Friday.

;

;'Geopolitical tensions could further hurt Hong Kong's global corruption ranking'

;

;The Hospital Authority rendered full assistance during its investigation into the case, the anti-graft agency said.

;

;“The ICAC reminds public servants to uphold a high standard of integrity through education and publicity, so as to meet public expectations and maintain public trust,” it said.

;Chinese police appear to have stepped up their crackdown on cryptocurrency-related crimes in recent months – and their big seizures in a few prominent cases show how people are using virtual currency to bypass Beijing's strict controls over the yuan.

;

;With the yuan having gradually depreciated against the US dollar this year, reaching a rate of 7:1 for the fourth time since 2019, capital outflows have been on the rise. A higher yuan number means it takes more yuan to buy a US dollar, and the yuan is currently about 6.5 per cent weaker than it was a year ago.

;

;On Tuesday, police in Jingmen, Hubei province, discussed an online gambling case in which virtual currencies were widely used to avoid regulation. It was said to involve 400 billion yuan (US$55.4 billion) worth of total turnover circulation, and more than 50,000 people.

;

;Police did not say which virtual currency was used but said they had already managed to freeze multiple accounts with a combined value of US$160 million.

;

;Chinese economist calls for review of rigid crypto ban amid slow e-CNY adoption

;

;In a separate case on Monday, police in the central province of Shanxi said they had busted a money-laundering case involving 380 million yuan worth of USDT, a stablecoin issued by Hong Kong-based company Tether to mirror the price of the US dollar.

;

;The State Administration of Foreign Exchange, the nation's forex regulator, has implemented a variety of measures to monitor cross-border capital flows.

;

;It also fines violators – 10 firms or individuals were fined in late June – to “help maintain the forex market order”.

;

;The recent virtual currency cases, however, shed light on loopholes in China's capital control system.

;

;Chinese regulators have long banned the mining and trading of cryptocurrencies such as bitcoin and Ethereum, citing their perceived threats to the financial system.

;

;And for the past few years, Beijing has been rolling out its central bank digital currency – known as the e-yuan, or e-CNY – with a series of ongoing pilot programmes across the country. This is China's official currency in digital form, with the same value, transferable like cash using an app.

;

;Many cryptocurrency miners or traders have subsequently gone underground or moved overseas, including Hong Kong, which could become a cryptocurrency hub.

;

;The persistent depreciation of the yuan this year, due to its widened yield differential with the US dollar, has added to the capital outflow pressure.

;

;Foreign investors sold Chinese debt for the sixth consecutive month in June, even as emerging Asia saw strong inflows of funds, according to the Institute of International Finance.

;

;A total of US$1.59 billion was removed from China's debt last month, compared with US$4.19 billion in May, its data showed.

;

;Chinese equities posted US$1.93 billion worth of inflows from overseas funds in June, the IIF said, compared with May inflows of US$126 million.

;

;Foreign fund managers have also been selling vast amounts of Chinese securities over the past two years in response to Chinese policies and mounting US-China tensions, according to an Atlantic Council report last month.

;

;“International institutional investors have been net sellers of about 1 trillion yuan of the country's bonds since early 2022,” the report said.

;Mainland China will sell 12 billion yuan (US$1.66 billion) of government bonds in Hong Kong next month as Beijing continues its efforts to promote its currency internationally and tap cheaper funds as the yield gap with the US widens.

;

;The debt will be offered starting from August 2, China's finance ministry said in a statement on its website on Wednesday. The specifics of the flotation will be disclosed on the Central Moneymarkets Unit of the Hong Kong Monetary Authority (HKMA).

;

;The tranche is part of 30 billion yuan of sovereign bonds mainland China plans to issue in Hong Kong this year. Last month, the finance ministry raked in 12 billion yuan when it sold the first batch of the offshore bonds in the city, drawing strong demand from investors.

;

;The maturities of those bonds were two years, three years and 10 years, with the coupon rates ranging from 2.2 per cent to 2.71 per cent.

;

;Demand for yuan-denominated financial products has been increasing in offshore markets such as Hong Kong, as countries from Brazil to Saudi Arabia agree to ditch the US dollar and use the Chinese currency in trade settlements.

;

;At the same time Hong Kong aims to entrench its status as a global financial hub by promoting the internalisation of the Chinese currency.

;

;The city is now the world's biggest market for the offshore yuan, processing about 75 per cent of settlements involving the currency globally. It was home to 1 trillion yuan in offshore yuan deposits as of the end of last year.

;

;China is banking on the divergence of its monetary policies from those of other major global economies for cheaper fundraising. The People's Bank of China lowered both its policy rate and the loan prime rate by 10 basis points last month, and more cuts are expected to follow in the rest of the year to bolster growth.

;

;Meanwhile, the Federal Reserve is widely expected to raise the benchmark US borrowing costs by at least once this year to quell sticky inflation.

;

;The yield spread between 10-year government bonds in the US and China stands at 1.13 percentage points now, having widened from 1.05 percentage points at the start of the year, according to Bloomberg data.

;

;To enrich the range of financial products based on the yuan, the Hong Kong stock exchange launched a dual-counter trading facility last month, which allows local and overseas investors to convert between the yuan and the Hong Kong dollar when trading 24 selected companies including Tencent Holdings and Alibaba Group.

;

;Eddie Yue Wai-man, the chief executive officer of the HKMA, said at a conference in June that the next major product in the offing might be the launch of offshore futures in Chinese government bonds.

;

;August's bond offering will mark the 15th straight year that China has sold yuan-denominated government bonds in Hong Kong. The finance ministry has raised 273 billion yuan from sales of offshore debt in total.
